title: Real Wages and the Great Depression
abstractText:
This project is designed to cast new light on one of the major unresolved issues of the Great Depression.  Were real wages downwardly inflexible - as many earlier researchers contest - in the face of exceptional declines in economic activity?

Most previous empirical investigations have been based on highly aggregate data, usually at national or 1-digit industry levels.  One major consequence is that measures of cyclical wage responsiveness have been subject to composition bias.  A negative demand shock will lead to disproportionate losses of less productive, lower-paid, workers and a disproportionate hiring of such workers in the subsequent upturn. This introduces a counter-cyclical wage movement that masks the true degree of wage rate cyclical responsiveness.

Using highly disaggregate payroll and working time data of British Engineering Employers Federation for the years 1928 to 1937, this project will attempt to assess the effects of biases resulting from data aggregation.  In addition to workforce compositional effects, it will assess:

  • the role played by fluctuations in overtime working,
  • the consequences of separating time- and piece-rated workers, and
  • the implications of failing to measure cyclical effects at local geographical levels.
